marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Joseph Hewes was a merchant, N.C. delegate to the Continental Congress, and signer of the Declaration of Independence.
Letter from John Campbell to Hewes describing the public attitude in North Carolina, general distress and inflation, coinage weights and values, and the need for a mint.
Joseph B. Hill was a esident of Muscogee County, Georgia.
Letter; and two legal papers which relate to the sale of land to Hill.
Richard Newton Hewitt was a Confederate Army physician, from "Otter Oaks," Campbell County, Virginia.

Principally the Civil War correspondence of R.N. Hewitt containing comments on personal affairs, the difficulties of army life, prices of salt and supplies, the first battle of Bull Run, the blockade of Southern ports, prisoners, picket duty, troop movements, food, clothing, sickness, hospitals, a measles epidemic, music, and various Confederate and Union officers and leaders. Other personal correspondence refers to commodity prices, slaves, religion, weather and crops, the settlement of estates, the University of Virginia and its students and social life, and railroads.
William A. Hightower was a college student and Confederate soldier, from Halifax County, Virginia.

Letters written while Hightower was a student at Randolph-Macon College, Boydton, Virginia, 1859-1860, and while serving in the Confederate Army. The majority of the collection concerns Hightower's college life, but his Civil War letters discuss various skirmishes under Stonewall Jackson's command.
Thomas Wentworth Higginson was a minister, Army officer, author, and social reformer, of Cambridge, Massachusetts.

Letters by Higginson, mainly relating to literary and personal matters and to lectures delivered by him. Includes "The Nonsense of It. Short Answers to Common Objections against Woman Suffrage." Addressees include William Bliss Carman, Daniel Coit Gilman, Julia Ward Howe, Charles Henry Miller, John Codman Ropes, and Laird Simons. In an 1854 letter to an unidentified recipient, Higginson wrote regarding "free church" organizations that might offer suitable positions, sent a "cheap" tract on women's rights, and requested a "unprejudiced account" of New York Central College in McGrawville, New York. In a 1897 letter, he wrote to a book club organizer regarding a reprinting.
Silas Highby was a resident of Oneida County, New York.
Letters from Orra Garvin to Silas Highby and his wife dealing with personal and family matters.
A. P. Hill was a Confederate army general.
Collection consists of a letter, 1856, from Hill, later a Confederate general, to Carrie Redfield discussing personal matters. There are also comments, 1862, written on the letter by Redfield.
Alma Hibbard was a Northern teacher who lived and worked in the home of Bishop William Meade in Clarke County, Virginia.
Journal (120 pages) by Hibbard contains comments on the Meade household; social life, customs, peculiarities of speech in the area; and slavery.
Thomas Hicks was a summer resident of Trenton Falls, Oneida County, New York.
Letter to Thomas Hicks from G. W. Van Derlip concerning possible revisions to a portrait which Hicks had completed.
D. H. Hill was an author, professor of mathematics at Washington and Lee, Confederate major-general, and later president of the University of Arkansas and Georgia Military College.

Collection contains miscellaneous letters and papers of Hill including scattered items pertaining to his service in the Confederate Army; a letter to C.C. Jones, Jr., concerning their love for the Confederacy; and materials relating to Hill's work as editor of THE LAND WE LOVE. Other items include a lodging bill; an 1863 order from Junius Daniel concerning troop movements in North Carolina; and a message from Hill to General Stevenson about miltary operations in North Carolina in the closing days of the conflict. One letter written to Hill while president of University of Arkansas, is from Thomas Fenwick Drayton. Drayton discusses Charlotte and gives information on the post-war activities of various officers from the Confederacy. Of Charlotte in 1878 Drayton notes: "The gamblers and saloon-men run this town."
Cataloged from Guide and accession records.
Francis H. Hill was a lawyer, merchant, postmaster, farmer, pension and claim agent, commissioner in chancery, and clerk in the county and county courts of Madison, Madison County, Virginia.
Letter, 1860, to Francis H. Hill from William Green discussing legal affairs; and a letter, 1861, by Hill concerning legal affairs, local and national politics, and secession.
H. Hetsler was a resident of Germantown, Montgomery County, Ohio and a Union soldier.
Letters of an Ohio soldier describing hardships of army life.
James Henry Hewett was a Confederate soldier with Co. F, 3rd Regiment, North Carolina State Troops, from New Hanover County, North Carolina.

Letters, written on pictorial stationery, from Hewett to his brother, describing his movements through North Carolina and Virginia. He was located in Wilmington, N.C. (1861), Acquia Creek, Va. (1861-1862), Goldsboro, N.C. (1862), and Richmond, Va. (1862). One letter includes a description of General Thomas Jonathan ("Stonewall") Jackson.
James Davidson Hill was a Confederate Army officer.

Miscellaneous letters and papers relating to Hill's service as an officer in the Confederate Army. The collection includes orders, reports on supplies and enemy troop movements, letters recommending Hill for promotion, and a letter, 1864, from a Louisiana planter to Admiral David Dixon Porter of the United States Navy seeking compensation for goods confiscated by Federal soldiers.
J. D. Hill was a Confederate soldier from Virginia.
Letters from J. D. Hill to his brother, William, describing financial matters and army life around Richmond and Centreville in 1862.
N. Hill was a Confederate soldier from York County, South Carolina.
Personal letters from N. Hill to his wife; and a letter from Fannie Nicholson, a student at Greensboro Female College, Greensboro, North Carolina.
Hicks, Jones & Mallory was a shoe shop in Lawrenceville, Virginia.
Business papers, bills, and receipts of Hicks, Jones, and Mallory. Also includes an accout book (80 pages) for 1864.
J. A. Hill was a resident of Albany, Georgia.
Letters pertaining to the Macon and Western Railroad.

George Nelson Hill was a farmer, Republican politician, state senator, and educator, of Northwest Township (Brunswick County), North Carolina. Former Union Army veteran, originally from Newton, Massachusetts.

Diary dated June 1869-August 1872 (156 pages) mainly concerns farming, including some references to rice, laborers, a grape and scuppernong vineyard and wine making; county Republican politics, politicians, and elections; and local persons and communities, including visits to Wilmington and Smithville. Other diary topics include: state Republican politics and elections; local churches; the school committee and the establishment of a black school; a visit to Newton, Massachusetts (1871-1872); a trip to the North Carolina coast (Aug. 1871); the burning of the C.S.S. North Carolina (Sept. 1871); and occasional references to blacks, the Ku Klux Klan, the Democratic opposition, a cooperative association (1872), and a local post of the Grand Army of the Republic (1872).

The volume also contains miscellancous records, 1869-1870s; farm accounts and memoranda, including accounts for men and women laborers; purchases of goods; travel expenses; and occasional notations about politicians and elections.

Addition includes letters from Hill to his niece "Eva." Contains letters from: Raleigh while he was in the North Carolina State Senate; Washington D.C., where he worked in the U.S. Treasury Department; Smithfield, North Carolina; and Wilmington, North Carolina.
Andrew Hickenlooper was a resident of Cincinnati, Hamilton County, Ohio.
Letter to Andrew Hickenlooper, Jr., from Schuyler Hamilton concerning the Society of the Army of the Tennessee. Includes an extract from the Society's Proceedings.
Society of the Army of the Tennessee.
T. D. Heyward was a resident of South Island, Georgetown County, South Carolina.

Two letters from Selma Heyward to her husband, T. D. Heyward, in Savannah, Georgia, describing earthquakes in South Carolina; and a special order issued by the Savannah Volunteer Guards ordering the holding of elections.

Harlow N. Higinbotham was a prominent Chicago (Ill.) merchant, philanthropist partner in the firm of Marshall Field & Co., a director of the World's Columbian Exposition (later the World's Fair) of 1893, the head of the Field Museum of Natural History, and had a number of personal benefactions such as the Chicago Home for Incurables.

A journal describing Higinbotham's travel to Kentucky and Tennessee in February 1886. He recorded his own impressions and the opinions of local residents such as a pro-Union Louisville (Kentucky) judge, and a Nashville (Tennessee) octogenarian. Topics include the general appearance of Louisville, lack of schools in Tennessee for both whites and blacks, visit with President Polk's widow, call on Governor Bates in Nashville, the Hermitage Club, Andrew Jackson, Vanderbilt and Southern education.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession records.
Fayette Hewitt was a Confederate Army officer from Frankfort, Franklin County, Kentucky.
A letter of Fayette Hewitt to Thomas D. Osborne concerning the return of bodies of soldiers killed in various battles, including Chickamauga; and a picture and biographical sketch of Hewitt.
